<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 280, 171, 291]]<|/det|> # PHYSICS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 393, 311]]<|/det|> Paper 2 AS Level Structured Questions <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 339, 415, 351]]<|/det|> Candidates answer on the Question Paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 359, 368, 370]]<|/det|> No Additional Materials are required. <|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 392, 388, 404]]<|/det|> # READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 419, 718, 431]]<|/det|> Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 434, 325, 445]]<|/det|> Write in dark blue or black pen. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 448, 503, 460]]<|/det|> You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 463, 504, 474]]<|/det|> Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 477, 380, 488]]<|/det|> DO **NOT** WRITE IN ANY BARCODES. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 503, 256, 514]]<|/det|> Answer **all** questions. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 528, 359, 540]]<|/det|> Electronic calculators may be used. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 543, 767, 555]]<|/det|> You may lose marks if you do not show your working or if you do not use appropriate units. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 568, 605, 580]]<|/det|> At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 583, 758, 595]]<|/det|> The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 124, 87]]<|/det|>
## Data  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 102, 666, 560]]<|/det|>
speed of light in free space \(c = 3.00\times 10^{8}\mathrm{ms}^{- 1}\) permeability of free space \(\mu_{0} = 4\pi \times 10^{- 7}\mathrm{Hm}^{- 1}\) permittivity of free space \(\epsilon_{0} = 8.85\times 10^{- 12}\mathrm{Fm}^{- 1}\) \((\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}} = 8.99\times 10^{9}\mathrm{mF}^{- 1})\) elementary charge \(e = 1.60\times 10^{- 19}\mathrm{C}\) the Planck constant \(h = 6.63\times 10^{- 34}\mathrm{Js}\) unified atomic mass unit \(1u = 1.66\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of electron \(m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11\times 10^{- 31}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of proton \(m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) molar gas constant \(R = 8.31\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Avogadro constant \(N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02\times 10^{23}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Boltzmann constant \(k = 1.38\times 10^{- 23}\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\) gravitational constant \(G = 6.67\times 10^{- 11}\mathrm{Nm}^{2}\mathrm{kg}^{- 2}\) acceleration of free fall \(g = 9.81\mathrm{ms}^{- 2}\)

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 167, 88]]<|/det|>
## Formulae

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 108, 560, 145]]<|/det|>
\[s = ut + \frac{1}{2} at^{2}\] \[\nu^{2} = u^{2} + 2as\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 163, 525, 179]]<|/det|>
\[W = p\Delta V\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 195, 536, 225]]<|/det|>
\[\phi = -\frac{Gm}{r}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 236, 521, 252]]<|/det|>
\[p = \rho gh\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 264, 560, 295]]<|/det|>
\[p = \frac{1}{3}\frac{Nm}{V}\langle c^2\rangle\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 305, 536, 321]]<|/det|>
\[a = -\omega^2 x\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 340, 612, 375]]<|/det|>
\[\nu = \nu_{0}\cos \omega t\] \[\nu = \pm \omega \sqrt{(\chi_{0}^{2} - x^{2})}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 380, 536, 415]]<|/det|>
\[f_{0} = \frac{f_{s}V}{\nu \pm \nu_{s}}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 425, 536, 459]]<|/det|>
\[V = \frac{Q}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}r}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[428, 468, 625, 485]]<|/det|>
\[1 / C = 1 / C_{1} + 1 / C_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 500, 595, 518]]<|/det|>
\[C = C_{1} + C_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 530, 525, 556]]<|/det|>
\[W = \frac{1}{2} QV\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 570, 530, 587]]<|/det|>
\[I = A n v q\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 604, 595, 621]]<|/det|>
\[R = R_{1} + R_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[428, 637, 625, 654]]<|/det|>
\[1 / R = 1 / R_{1} + 1 / R_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[434, 668, 518, 700]]<|/det|>
\[V_{H} = \frac{BI}{ntq}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 715, 558, 732]]<|/det|>
\[x = x_{0}\sin \omega t\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 747, 578, 765]]<|/det|>
\[x = x_{0}\exp (-\lambda t)\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 775, 536, 810]]<|/det|>
\[\lambda = \frac{0.693}{t_{\frac{1}{2}}}\]

Mass, length and time are all SI base quantities.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 243, 146, 261]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 243, 653, 260]]<|/det|>
A wire hangs between two fixed points, as shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 274, 808, 415]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 437, 590, 453]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 467, 918, 515]]<|/det|>
A child's swing is made by connecting a car tyre to the wire using a rope and a hook. The system is in equilibrium with the wire hanging at an angle of \(17^{\circ}\) to the horizontal. The tension in the wire is \(150 \text{N}\). Assume that the rope and hook have negligible weight.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 530, 180, 548]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 530, 465, 546]]<|/det|>
Determine the weight of the tyre.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[510, 668, 918, 685]]<|/det|>
<form>weight = ............................................................ N [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 96, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 144, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 73, 472, 90]]<|/det|>
State what is meant by kinetic energy.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 133, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 165, 148, 183]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 165, 920, 214]]<|/det|>
A cannon fires a shell vertically upwards. The shell leaves the cannon with a speed of \(80 \text{m s}^{-1}\) and a kinetic energy of \(480 \text{J}\). The shell then rises to a maximum height of \(210 \text{m}\). The effect of air resistance is significant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 228, 180, 246]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 228, 542, 246]]<|/det|>
Show that the mass of the shell is \(0.15 \text{kg}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 351, 920, 370]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 382, 181, 400]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 382, 850, 400]]<|/det|>
For the movement of the shell from the cannon to its maximum height, calculate

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 414, 567, 431]]<|/det|>
1. the gain in gravitational potential energy,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[267, 551, 920, 568]]<|/det|>
<pre>gain in gravitational potential energy = ............................................................ J [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 581, 220, 600]]<|/det|>
<label>2.</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[233, 581, 537, 600]]<|/det|>
the work done against air resistance.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[479, 675, 920, 692]]<|/det|>
<pre>work done = .................................................................... J [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 706, 180, 725]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 706, 920, 739]]<|/det|>
Determine the average force due to the air resistance acting on the shell as it moves from the cannon to its maximum height.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[522, 861, 920, 878]]<|/det|>
<pre>force = .................................................................... N [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 73, 180, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 73, 887, 90]]<|/det|>
The shell leaves the cannon at time \(t = 0\) and reaches maximum height at time \(t = T\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 104, 917, 135]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 2.1, sketch the variation with time \(t\) of the velocity \(v\) of the shell from time \(t = 0\) to time \(t = T\). Numerical values of \(v\) and \(t\) are not required.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[349, 148, 645, 335]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 352, 532, 368]]<|/det|>
<pre>Fig. 2.1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 368, 920, 386]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 399, 180, 416]]<|/det|>
<label>(v)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 399, 641, 415]]<|/det|>
The force due to the air resistance is a vector quantity.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 429, 917, 460]]<|/det|>
Compare the force due to the air resistance acting on the shell as it rises with the force due to the air resistance as it falls.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 630, 920, 647]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 12]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 96, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 146, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 468, 90]]<|/det|>
State Newton's second law of motion.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 135, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 165, 146, 183]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 165, 863, 182]]<|/det|>
A toy rocket consists of a container of water and compressed air, as shown in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[274, 193, 727, 422]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 441, 532, 459]]<|/det|>
<pre>Fig. 3.1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 472, 920, 505]]<|/det|>
Water is pushed vertically downwards through a nozzle by the compressed air. The rocket moves vertically upwards.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 520, 918, 568]]<|/det|>
The nozzle has a circular cross-section of radius \(7.5\mathrm{mm}\) . The density of the water is \(1000\mathrm{kg}\mathrm{m}^{- 3}\) . Assume that the water leaving the nozzle has the shape of a cylinder of radius \(7.5\mathrm{mm}\) and has a constant speed of \(13\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{- 1}\) relative to the rocket.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 583, 180, 600]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 583, 918, 615]]<|/det|>
Show that the mass of water leaving the nozzle in the first 0.20s after the rocket launch is \(0.46kg\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 770, 920, 787]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 73, 181, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 275, 90]]<|/det|>
Calculate

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 104, 917, 121]]<|/det|>
1. the change in the momentum of the mass of water in **(b)**(i) due to leaving the nozzle,

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[384, 180, 917, 198]]<|/det|>
\[\text{change in momentum} = \text{....................................................................} \text{Ns}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 211, 217, 230]]<|/det|>
<label>2.</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[232, 211, 670, 230]]<|/det|>
the force exerted on this mass of water by the rocket.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[522, 288, 917, 306]]<|/det|>
<form>force = ........................................................................... $N$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 305, 918, 323]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 335, 180, 354]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 335, 917, 369]]<|/det|>
State and explain how Newton's third law applies to the movement of the rocket by the water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 475, 181, 492]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 475, 917, 524]]<|/det|>
The container has a mass of \(0.40kg\) . The initial mass of water before the rocket is launched is \(0.70kg\) . The mass of the compressed air in the rocket is negligible. Assume that the resistive force on the rocket due to its motion is negligible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 537, 593, 554]]<|/det|>
For the rocket at a time of \(0.20s\) after launching,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 568, 514, 585]]<|/det|>
1. show that its total mass is \(0.64kg\),

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 660, 443, 677]]<|/det|>
2. calculate its acceleration.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 850, 918, 867]]<|/det|>
<form>acceleration = .................................................................... $m s^{-2}$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 866, 918, 884]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 73, 918, 106]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 384, 918, 418]]<|/det|>
A horizontal string is stretched between two fixed points X and Y. A vibrator is used to oscillate the string and produce a stationary wave. Fig. 4.2 shows the string at one instant in time.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 434, 806, 508]]<|/det|>
<center>Fig. 4.2</center>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 611, 181, 630]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 94, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 917, 106]]<|/det|>
A particle of mass \(m\) and charge \(q\) is in a uniform electric field of strength \(E\). The particle has acceleration \(a\) due to the field.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 120, 148, 136]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 120, 244, 135]]<|/det|>
Show that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 129, 534, 158]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{q}{m} = \frac{a}{E}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 274, 920, 292]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 305, 148, 323]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 305, 917, 338]]<|/det|>
The particle has a charge of \(4e\) where \(e\) is the elementary charge. The electric field strength is \(3.5 \times 10^{4} \text{V} \text{m}^{-1}\). The acceleration of the particle is \(1.5 \times 10^{12} \text{m} \text{s}^{-2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 351, 733, 369]]<|/det|>
Use the expression in (a) to show that the mass of the particle is 9.0u.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 510, 920, 528]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[411, 587, 915, 605]]<|/det|>
\[\text{number of protons} = \text{...........................................................................}\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[402, 619, 915, 636]]<|/det|>

<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 664, 912, 682]]<|/det|>
A second nucleus that is an isotope of the nucleus in (c) is in the same uniform electric field.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 696, 917, 728]]<|/det|>
State and explain whether the electric field produces, for the two nuclei, the same magnitudes of

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 743, 188, 761]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 743, 245, 761]]<|/det|>
force,
